key_points: Prince Harry discusses Meghan Markle's reaction to bullying allegations ahead of their Oprah interview in his docuseries 'The Me You Can't See'.
The allegations, reported by The Times, claimed Meghan faced a bullying complaint from a close adviser during her time as a royal, which she strongly refuted.
Harry described Meghan's distress over the smear campaign by the media and the firm, leading her to cry inconsolably.
The Duke of Sussex reflected on the positive impact of therapy on his mental health and relationship with Meghan.
He credits Meghan for encouraging him to seek therapy, which helped him address unresolved issues from his childhood.
Prince Harry emphasizes the importance of mental health and says therapy enabled him to handle anything.
The couple, having resigned as working royals in March 2020, now reside in Montecito, California with their son Archie.
They are expecting their second child, a girl, and have ventured into business with Netflix and Spotify, and their Archewell Foundation.
Harry and Meghan recently celebrated their third wedding anniversary.
The Me You Can't See will be available on Apple TV+ from May 20 at 9 p.m. ET.
spokespersons: Spokesperson for the Duke and Duchess of Sussex
